editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I received your letter last night, containing Richard’s poems. I think "Prayer" and "Bondage" are very beautiful. Whether or not I can sell them at once I do not know. You see, I have already done considerable selling of Richard’s things of late. Papers like "The Seven Arts" I do not think are very understanding in Imagist work. I fear "The Poetry Review" is rather filled up to the present, and I know there is no use in asking Harriet to buy more until she has published those she has. I think I shall try "The Century" with one of these; but that is a very problematic amusement. Anyway, I will see what I can do to get them into something, and to get the best price for them.

You will be glad to know that our old Anthology – the 1915 one – has just had to be reprinted for the third time. We sold over fifty copies of it in the last month. Also Constable has ordered 165 copies of the 1916 Anthology, 15 of these for review purposes, making 150 for sale. That is not so bad. Do keep your eyes out for the criticisms, and let me have them.

I see that Martyn Johnson has announced Richard as one of his contributors to "The Dial," which he has just bought. He was so in love with Richard’s paper on Henry de Régnier that I think he will take a good deal of Richard’s prose work. They publish no poetry. "The Dial" is not a general magazine, it is a magazine of criticism only, criticism in all the arts, so that any articles on the war or anything of that sort would not be pertinent. But any critical article that Richard feels like sending, I am sure would meet with consideration.

I have told "The Dial" and everybody else with whom I have to do that I am acting here as Richard’s agent, and that they must send their cheques to me. By this process I know when he has been paid, and also I am on the spot and can enforce payment. "The Poetry Review" wrote me the other day and asked me to whom they should send his cheque for the Mallarmé article, which was published this month, and I told them to send it to me; it has not come yet, and I suppose it won’t for some little time; but I hope to have it before long.

There is not much to tell you. I am busy with the proofs of my new book, as I suppose you are with yours. I have also written some poems. I wish I could see you all, but I trust the war will not last forever. Now I must go back to my proofs.
With a great deal of love from Mrs. Russell and me to you and Richard,
